news.title: Here's How The Coronavirus First Ended Up In CT: Yale Study
news.summary: CONNECTICUT — Gov. Ned Lamont recently said April would be a "horrible" month concerning the outbreak of the coronavirus in Connecticut.

news.title: Interstate transmission of COVID-19 is now most urgent threat
news.summary: Connecticut samples of SARS-CoV-2 (light blue) are closely associated with virus samples collected in Washington state (dark purple) indicating that transcontinental spread of the virus was occurring by mid-March.

news.title: Most New York Coronavirus Cases Came From Europe, Genomes Show
news.summary: New research indicates that the coronavirus began to circulate in the New York area by mid-February, weeks before the first confirmed case, and that travelers brought in the virus mainly from Europe, not Asia.

news.title: Most New York coronavirus cases came from Europe, as Genomes Show shows

news.title: Genetic Tracking Helped Us Fight Ebola. Why Can’t It Halt COVID-19?
news.summary: In late 2018, a paper in the journal Nature Microbiology proposed a hypothetical scenario: A young man comes into a Miami hospital with flu-like symptoms and dies of a mysterious pneumonia within days.

news.title: What can we learn from the genomes of the novel coronavirus?
news.summary: COVID-19 is the disease caused by the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2. “Bad news wrapped in a protein”, as a recent news story(link is external) put it, is an apt epithet for this virus which has brought life as we know it to a stand still.

blogs.title: Genetic analysis of the coronavirus gives scientists clues about how it’s spreading
blogs.summary: As the coronavirus spreads around the globe, it has mutated in tiny, subtle ways. Those mutations aren’t cause for concern, and so far, don’t appear…

blogs.title: Racing a pandemic – Yale scientists design new ways of tracking COVID-19
blogs.summary:
In a perfect scenario, individual COVID-19 testing would be widely and readily accessible. In reality, tests are still in short supply, and likely cases far outnumber testing capacity, making the prevalence and trajectory of the disease hard to measure.
B

wikipedia.title: Emma Hodcroft
wikipedia.summary: Emma Hodcroft (born 1986 in Norway) is a British-American molecular epidemiologist at the Institute for Social and Preventive Medicine at the University of Bern.
